persona.name: Janet Marie Carlson

occupation.title: Retired School Librarian / Library Media Technician (retired)
occupation.organization: Duluth Area Schools (retired 2013) — earlier employed at Lincoln Middle School and later at Central High School
occupation.description: Janet worked for nearly four decades in public school libraries and district-level literacy initiatives. Her responsibilities included managing the school library collection (circulation, cataloging, selection), teaching student research skills, coordinating reading incentives, training teachers to use library resources, organizing author visits and book fairs, and supervising volunteers and student aides. In the last five years before retirement she served as a part-time district literacy coordinator overseeing summer reading programs, evaluation of reading materials for grade-level appropriateness, and grant writing for early-literacy kits. She gained practical management skills (small-budget oversight, scheduling, supervising 4-6 staff or aides), public speaking at staff meetings and PTA nights, basic grant application work, and strong classroom management when instructing groups of students. After formal retirement she substituted twice a month at the local elementary school and volunteered weekly at the county library's children's program.

persona.residence: Duluth, Minnesota (midsized Midwestern city; lives in an older bungalow within walking distance of the downtown library and bus routes)
persona.education: High School Diploma (Duluth Central High School, 1969). Attended Lake Superior Community College in the 1970s; completed an Associate of Applied Science in Library Technical Assistant / Library Technology (1975). Took periodic continuing-education workshops through the regional school district and the state library association on early literacy, cataloging (Dewey) updates, and community programming. Informal coursework: bookkeeping basics through adult-education evening classes in the 1980s.
long_term_goals: Maintain independence and mobility as long as possible, so she can remain in her home and neighborhood.
Leave behind a modest but meaningful legacy: a small endowment (through her estate) for the children's reading program at the county library.
Be actively present for her grandchildren's life milestones and ensure at least one scholarship fund in the community library bears her late husband's name.
Continue to learn and try one new practical skill each year (e.g., basic tablet photo editing, a new quilting pattern).
Age with dignity and minimal burden on her adult children while staying socially engaged and useful in the community.
persona.style: Warm, distinctly Midwestern in cadence with a soft, slightly nasal Minnesota accent when relaxed; more clipped and careful when speaking in public or during formal events. Uses plain, conversational English with a habit of peppering speech with small local references ('up the hill,' 'out by the harbor'). Conservative but practical wardrobe: cardigans, sensible low-heeled shoes, patterned cotton dresses in summer, and a favored green wool coat in winter. Mannerisms: folds her hands when listening, tilts her head slightly before answering, laughs with a small exhale rather than a big guffaw. Speaks politely, often prefacing opinions with 'I think' or 'In my experience.' When excited about a book or program she speaks quickly and her hands move to emphasize points, but otherwise she keeps gestures minimal. Prefers handwritten thank-you notes for favors and gifts; keeps a small leather-bound planner and a library-themed tote bag almost always at hand. Digital style: competent email user, reads news on tablet, posts occasional photos of grandchildren on Facebook but avoids political argumentation on social media. When frustrated she sighs, gives a dry observation, and then quickly focuses on solutions rather than lingering on the complaint.

traits: Pragmatic and solution-focused: prefers actionable steps over rumination.
Emotionally resilient: recovered from several losses (notably the death of her husband) with steady optimism and adaptive coping.
Quietly sociable: enjoys small groups, book club conversation, and one-on-one visits rather than large, noisy gatherings.
Detail-oriented: meticulous with records, recipes, and her quilting patterns.
Dependable and punctual: shows up on time, finishes volunteer shifts, keeps promises to friends and family.
Selective about intimacy: maintains a circle of trusted friends rather than a broad social network.
Nurturing and patient with children and students; a natural mentor.
Mildly stubborn when it comes to matters of principle or routine.
Frugal and financially cautious but willing to spend on family experiences and community causes.
Curious and moderately open to new ideas — will try new technology if there's a clear benefit.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness is moderate-high for cultural and literary interests but practical rather than avant-garde. Highly conscientious: organized, reliable, and duty-oriented. Low extraversion: prefers small groups and solitary pursuits. Agreeable and cooperative but capable of firmness. Low neuroticism: generally calm and resilient under stress.

interests: Children's and young-adult literature (classic Judy Blume, Lois Lowry, modern MG authors like Kate DiCamillo)
Local history — particularly Duluth maritime and mining heritage
Gardening: perennial beds, heirloom tomatoes, and raised-bed vegetables
Quilting and needlework — prefers traditional patchwork patterns and Mennonite-style quilts
Community volunteering — library story hours, Meals on Wheels delivery twice a month
Classical radio programs and NPR - Morning Edition and local talk segments
Baking: sourdough bread, cinnamon rolls, lemon bars
Walking along the lakeshore and birdwatching in spring
Watching public television documentaries and Masterpiece Theatre dramas
Attending author talks and small cultural events at the community college
Listening to a mix of oldies, folk, and light country music (Dolly Parton, John Prine, Simon & Garfunkel)
Collecting first editions of regional authors
Crossword puzzles and daily word games (NYT Crossword in easier mode)
Knit blankets for newborns at the county hospital
Occasional day trips to the neighboring small towns for antique shopping
Supporting local bakeries and a small downtown coffee shop she favors
Light woodworking — building raised beds and a bench for the front porch
Genealogy research for the Carlson and Erickson branches of her family
Attending the monthly women's book club (meets at the library) and sharing potluck dishes
Watching her grandchildren's soccer games and attending school recitals
likes: Quiet mid-morning walks with a thermos of tea
The smell of old books and library stacks
Simple, well-made clothing and comfortable shoes
Handwritten notes and cards
Slow-cooked stews on blustery winter afternoons
Locally roasted dark roast coffee from the town roaster (medium-dark; prefers pour-over)
Window seats in restaurants and cafes
Good lighting for reading — a warm side lamp in the living room
Community potlucks and senior-center lunches that feature familiar faces
Seasonal rituals: raking leaves in fall, making preserves in late summer
Small-town festivals like the Fall Harvest Fair
Programs that put books into children's hands (Little Free Library donations)
Plain yogurt with honey and sliced peaches in summer
Listening to grandchildren tell long, excited stories
A tidy kitchen and labeled spice jars
Radio dramas on cold evenings
Baking with her daughter and passing on recipes
Well-organized public spaces and helpful signage
Talking to teenagers about books and encouraging them without being preachy
Simple but thoughtful gifts — a warm scarf, a used book in excellent condition
dislikes: Loud, crowded shopping malls and big-box weekend rushes
Aggressive telemarketers and fundraising calls
Fast-fashion throwaway clothing and excessive waste
Being rushed through a conversation or a program presentation
Unreliable public services (late buses, inconsistent library hours)
Political shouting matches at family gatherings
Digital-only communications when a face-to-face or phone call would be better
Restaurants that don't accommodate dietary needs for older guests
Unclear labels on medications or food ingredients
When young children are dismissed instead of guided in public spaces
Car horns as a persistent background noise
Books with gratuitous profanity when it adds no literary value
Overly spicy food (prefers gentle flavors)
Scams targeted at seniors and senior-targeted fraud
Messy or cluttered communal areas in the library or church halls
Volunteers who don't show up after committing
Being patronized because of her age
Predatory financial schemes aimed at retirees
Poorly heated public buildings in winter
Rudeness from service staff without apology
food_and_drink_details: Favorite breakfast: steel-cut oatmeal with sliced apples and cinnamon, occasionally with a dollop of molasses
Coffee: medium-dark roast, morning pour-over at home; prefers local bakery's house blend for outings
Tea: prefers Earl Grey in the afternoon, chamomile at night
Bakes weekly: sourdough loaves on Sundays and a batch of cinnamon rolls for special family brunches
Dislikes overly processed snacks; favors fruit, nuts, and homemade bars
Market preferences: buys seasonal produce at the farmer's market; favors heirloom tomato vendors in August
Salt preference: moderate; uses sea salt and watches sodium intake for blood pressure reasons
Enjoys occasional fish — baked trout or cod from local suppliers
Prefers simple desserts: fruit crisps, lemon bars, or a small slice of pound cake
media_and_tech_preferences: Reads print books most of the time; uses a tablet for large-type e-books and news websites
Listens to NPR and Minnesota Public Radio for news; occasionally watches PBS
Uses Facebook primarily to keep up with family photos and community events; does not engage in political debates online
Prefers telephone calls from family rather than long text-message threads
Uses a basic smartphone (large-text settings enabled) and a tablet for emails and photos
Relies on the public library's digital catalog and OverDrive for occasional e-book borrowing
Avoids smart home devices that record or listen continuously

beliefs: A well-run public library is essential to a healthy community.
Early childhood literacy is the single best investment for long-term educational outcomes.
Education should be practical, accessible, and foster curiosity rather than rote memorization.
Local civic engagement matters more than distant national cynicism; small actions add up.
Elections should be fair and transparent; she is confident in the fairness of elections.
Fiscal prudence in retirement is important: live modestly and plan for unexpected medical costs.
Grandparents have a duty to support and not supplant parents — offer help, not judgment.
Volunteering is a reciprocal act: the volunteer gives time but also derives purpose and social connection.
People deserve respect regardless of age; ageism is a persistent problem.
Libraries should resist censorship and protect intellectual freedom.
Technology is a tool; it is beneficial when it increases access and harms when it replaces human contact.
Community rituals (fairs, potlucks, school plays) maintain social fabric and should be cherished.
There is dignity in doing small useful things — making soup for a sick neighbor, delivering a library book.
Government should provide basic safety nets: reasonable healthcare access, support for seniors, and funding for public education.
Climate change is real; small local actions (tree planting, reducing waste) matter even if large solutions are needed.
Healthcare providers should listen to patients; the best outcomes come from shared decision-making.
Religious faith is a personal compass for many; she respects differing beliefs but tends toward a mainline Protestant outlook.
Personal responsibility is important, but community support systems are necessary when people fail.
Media should be consumed critically; sensational headlines are not a reliable guide to reality.
Libraries and schools must adapt to changing demographics and teach digital literacy.
There is value in intergenerational relationships for mutual learning and emotional balance.
People should be careful with debt; avoid high-interest loans and exploitative schemes.
Good neighbors are more important than distant acquaintances; social capital is built locally.
She believes in measured optimism: accept reality but look for workable improvements.
Respect for craftsmanship and hands-on skills (gardening, carpentry, quilting) is underappreciated.
Mental health is health; older adults should seek help when needed and should not be ashamed of therapy.
Cultural institutions (libraries, museums) should be funded at levels that allow staff to do meaningful work.
Public transportation and walkable neighborhoods make cities better for older adults.
One should pass on skills and stories — family recipes, genealogy, and community history are valuable legacies.
People should read widely, including books that challenge their viewpoints.
Law and order are important, but justice systems should be tempered by compassion, rehabilitation, and fairness.
Small local businesses deserve community support; they sustain local employment and culture.
Skepticism of flashy health fads; prefer evidence-based advice and regular primary-care relationships.
Children should be given responsibility appropriate to age to build confidence and competence.
Voting is a civic duty and should be exercised even when choices are imperfect.
Privacy matters; personal data should be protected by companies and governments.
End-of-life planning (advance directive, power of attorney) is a kind and responsible act for family members.
skills: Library cataloging (Dewey Decimal System), selection, and weeding of children's and young-adult collections
Storytelling and running engaging children's read-aloud sessions
Basic grant writing and small-budget management for literacy programs
Teaching research skills to middle- and high-school students (evaluating sources, citations)
Event organization: coordinating author visits, book fairs, and school-based reading contests
Public speaking in small to medium community settings and school assemblies
Volunteer coordination and mentorship of student aides
Basic bookkeeping and check-reconciliation from years managing small program budgets
Gardening and seasonal planting schedules; knowledge of cold-hardy Midwestern varieties
Quilting, sewing, and hand-stitching; can repair small garments and sew simple alterations
Baking (yeast bread, pastries), preserves, and food canning with food-safety awareness
Basic first aid and CPR (certified in the past and recertified intermittently)
Competent use of email, word processing (large-print setup), library digital catalogs, and tablet-based reading apps
Simple woodworking: building raised garden beds, repairing porch railings
Oral history interviewing and basic genealogy research using local archives
Active listening and conflict-diffusing communication in tense volunteer situations
Meal planning suitable for low-sodium dietary needs
Organizational skills: scheduling, lists, and checklists that keep programs running smoothly
Adaptation to new software when necessary (e.g., library circulation systems) though prefers a gradual learning curve
Driving in winter conditions: experienced, cautious, and prepares for storms

general: Arrives early to volunteer shifts and meetings; dislikes being late.
Prefers to do small acts of service rather than grand gestures (making a casserole, knitting a baby blanket).
Keeps a daily to-do list in a small paper planner and updates it each night.
Uses a habit of asking two questions after a presentation to clarify and show interest.
When reading a good book, she writes a short note in the flyleaf with the date and why she liked it.
Tends to decline political arguments at family meals, steering conversation toward shared memories or books.
When upset she retreats to the garden to work off emotions and thinks through a response.
Keeps a box of emergency library books (large print) for when mobility is limited after bad weather.
Prefers face-to-face contact for important matters, but will schedule phone calls when distance requires it.
Donates gently used children's books to the Little Free Library or school programs annually.

morning: Wakes reliably between 6:15 and 6:45 a.m.; starts the day with light stretching and a 20–30 minute walk if weather permits.
Has breakfast around 7:00 a.m.: typically oatmeal or toast and coffee/tea.
Checks emails and the community library volunteer schedule by 8:00 a.m.
Tends to read a chapter of a book or the paper before starting chores.
daily: Spends an hour in the garden or on a quilting project in the afternoon.
Does neighborhood errands mid-morning — visits the post office, bakery, or library dropbox.
Calls her eldest child (usually the daughter) once every two or three days to check in.
Reads for pleasure at least an hour daily, often in a chair by the window.
Completes a short household maintenance task each day to avoid big chores piling up.
weekly: Volunteers at the county library children's morning story hour on Thursday mornings.
Attends a senior-walking group at the community center on Tuesdays.
Meets with the women's book club on the first Monday of each month.
Goes to Sunday morning services at a local mainline Protestant church and attends coffee hour afterward.
Does laundry and deeper house cleaning on Saturdays and bakes on Sundays.
seasonal_or_yearly: Rakes leaves and prepares perennial beds in October; plants bulbs in late fall.
Makes jam and preserves in late summer; shares jars with family and neighbors.
Takes a winter trip to visit grandchildren in warmer climates every 2–3 years.
Participates in the county fair every summer by entering a pie or a quilt in local competitions.
Declutters shelves and donates books each spring.

health.summary: Generally good health for her age, active and mobile with strong sleep hygiene and low stress. Manages a couple of common age-related conditions with routine medical care.
details: Regular primary-care visits every 6 months; has a long-term relationship with a local family physician.
Mild osteoarthritis in her knees and occasional stiffness in winter; manages with low-impact exercise, stretching, and over-the-counter analgesics as needed.
Borderline hypertension diagnosed in her late 60s; controlled with low-dose medication, dietary moderation (reduced sodium), and regular walks.
Hearing: mild presbycusis (age-related high-frequency hearing loss); uses a single discreet hearing aid in the right ear for public programs and noisy rooms.
Vision: presbyopia corrected with progressive reading glasses; cataract surgery on the left eye in 2018 with a good outcome.
Sleep: highly regular schedule (lights out about 10:00 p.m., up by 6:30 a.m.); rarely has insomnia or stress-related sleep disruption.

Mental health: emotionally resilient, experienced grief counseling after her husband's death, uses social and volunteer networks to maintain wellbeing; no history of major depressive disorder in recent years.
Mobility: independent with a walker kept in the closet as a precaution but rarely used; can climb stairs slowly.
Vaccinations: up-to-date (influenza annually, shingles vaccine, COVID-19 primary series and recommended boosters as advised by her physician).
Dietary needs: generally balanced diet, mindful of sodium due to hypertension, enjoys moderate portions; sees a dietitian once after a workshop at the community center to tweak meals.
Medication management: keeps a weekly pill organizer and a list of all medications and supplements in her wallet.
Emergency planning: has an advance directive and medical power of attorney naming her daughter as the primary contact.

entries.name: Peter Carlson (late)
entries.notes: High-school sweetheart; worked in small-scale manufacturing; they were married for 48 years. Peter's death from a stroke was a major life transition; Janet honors his memory through small routines and the annual picnic scholarship named after him.

entries.name: Claire Jensen
entries.notes: Lives in Minneapolis with two children; works as a nurse practitioner. Close relationship: Claire visits monthly (or more), coordinates care matters, and is the primary emergency contact.

entries.name: Mark Carlson
entries.notes: Lives nearby in Duluth, single, works in municipal public works. Often helps with heavier chores and snow removal; enjoys tinkering with cars together.

entries.name: Ethan and Lila Jensen
entries.notes: Janet enjoys attending their school concerts and soccer games; buys reading prizes and sometimes arranges weekend sleepovers.

entries.name: Sister: Margaret (Maggie) Olsen
entries.notes: Lives in a smaller town two hours away; calls weekly; they exchange letters and recipes and grew up close.

entries.name: Daughter-in-law: Sara (married to Mark)
entries.notes: Good rapport; shares holiday responsibilities and coordinates family gatherings.

entries.name: Dorothy Kim
entries.notes: Met through the women's book club about 12 years ago; they exchange library book recommendations, trade preserves, and carpool to author talks.

entries.name: George and Helen Moran
entries.notes: Neighbors across the street; they shovel each other's walks and meet for tea during holidays.

entries.name: Library Volunteer Circle
entries.notes: A small group of regular volunteers she relies on for support and social activity; they check in about appointments and share transport to medical visits if needed.

entries.name: Karen Reyes
entries.notes: Collaborated on grant applications and summer reading programs; they still exchange occasional emails about curriculum and local author events.

entries.name: Former principal: Robert Lang
entries.notes: Respectful professional relationship; appears at retirement celebrations and anniversary events when invited.

other_facts: Born in 1953 in a small lakeside town in northeastern Minnesota; parents were public-school teachers (mother) and a foreman at a local mill (father).
Grew up helping in the family's vegetable garden and learned canning from her maternal grandmother.
Married Peter Carlson at age 20; they lived in three homes over their marriage but always returned to the same neighborhood near the lake.
Learned to type on a manual typewriter in high school and later taught basic keyboarding to middle-school students when computers were introduced.
Has a modest life-insurance policy and a small retirement account supplemented by a pension from the school district; estate is planned to fund a small reading program at the county library.
Her favorite childhood book was The Secret Garden, which influenced her love of gardening and children's literature.
In the 1980s she started a Saturday sewing circle at the school that evolved into an annual community quilting bee to raise funds for library programming.
She keeps a small scrapbook of author visit photos and handwritten notes from students she taught decades ago.
Volunteered at the Meals on Wheels program for twelve years, often delivering on rainy days and chatting with recipients at the doorway.
Took a memorable trip to Minneapolis with the book club to see a traveling exhibition of American children's book illustrators.
Has a cat named Mabel (adopted from the county shelter) who prefers to sit on clean laundry and purr loudly during reading time.
Owns a small collection of vintage postcards featuring Minnesota lighthouses and sends them occasionally to out-of-state friends.
She once coordinated a literacy grant that provided 500 picture books to low-income families through a pediatric clinic partnership.
Keeps a folded handkerchief in her purse and a small magnifier for reading fine print on medicine bottles.
Her quilting includes a special 'memory block' quilt made from her husband's old shirts and a few of her daughter's baby clothes.
Was part of a neighborhood group that successfully petitioned the city to add a crosswalk near the elementary school after a near-miss incident with a child and a car.
She refuses to buy a brand-new car for environmental and economic reasons; drives a reliable five-year-old used sedan, maintained by Mark when needed.
Attended a grief-support group for 9 months after her husband's death and found solace in gardening and volunteer work.
Her son Mark taught her how to change a flat tire; she likes knowing the basics but prefers to call him for major car repairs.
In winter she keeps a small stash of dry crackers, bottled water, and a battery-powered radio in the house for storm-related power outages.
Has a favorite librarian's quote framed on her mantel: 'A library is a hospital for the mind.'
Participated in a local oral-history project, recording interviews with retired steelworkers about the region's industrial past.
She collects small ceramic mugs from towns she visits and uses them for everyday tea service.
Once met a regional children's book author at a conference and still keeps the signed copy she received.
She taught her grandchildren to make simple bread and is delighted when they remember steps and help in the kitchen.
Janet is the designated 'family historian' and has amassed a binder of family photos, birthdates, and anecdotes; she updates it after holiday gatherings.
She keeps a small list of 'books to give away' each spring and enjoys selecting volumes for neighbors and friends with particular tastes.
When the library faced a funding threat five years ago, she organized neighborhood letters and a small petition drive that contributed to keeping weekend hours open.
She has a soft spot for shy teenagers and often arranges a quiet corner in story hour where more introverted kids can participate with less pressure.
Her favorite time of year is early autumn when the garden still produces and the light becomes softer; she often takes long walks to photograph leaves.
Janet learned basic Spanish phrases at a community center class to better communicate with a neighbor who is a native Spanish speaker.
She has a small ritual of polishing her husband's old wristwatch every Sunday while listening to an old radio program.
Keeps a 'go-bag' with a sweater, important documents, medication list, and a spare pair of glasses in case she needs to leave quickly.
In high school she played the clarinet in the marching band; while she no longer plays, she enjoys listening to wind ensembles.
Her kitchen is wallpapered with a subtle blue pattern and features a small shelf of recipe cards where she tucks new dishes she wants to try.
She once missed a flight to a conference because she stopped to help a stranded motorist with kids; the driver was grateful and had to reschedule work but both remembered the kindness.
Has a simple ritual of reading aloud to her cat for five minutes each evening; she believes the routine soothes them both.
Janet keeps an annual handwritten letter to each grandchild on their birthday with one memory and a small wish for the coming year.
She volunteers to teach one summer writing workshop for elementary students each summer and prizes creativity over perfect grammar for young writers.
